Article.ArticleTitle: Preparation of HMn<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> lithium-ion sieves with low manganese dissolution loss for improved cycling stability.

AbstractText: Manganese-based lithium-ion sieves have become some of the promising adsorbents for extracting Li<sup>+</sup> from brines. However, manganese dissolution loss (MDL) severely impairs the stability and cyclicity of ion sieves. A novel ozone eluent was first developed to extract Li<sup>+</sup> from lithium manganese oxides, which decreased MDL decreased from 5.89% to 0.11%, and after ten regeneration cycles, the adsorption capacity retained 85.39% of the initial value, which was better than 55.15% when only hydrochloric acid (HCl) was used as the eluent. Based on these phenomena, the mechanism for the O<sub>3</sub> lowering of MDL was investigated. First, the catalytic decomposition reaction of O<sub>3</sub> competed with the disproportionation reaction, and the involvement of O<sub>3</sub> inhibited the occurrence of the disproportionation reaction. Additionally, the presence of O<sub>3</sub> and reactive oxygen species provided a preferential electron acceptor compared to Mn<sup>3+</sup> during the migration of electrons from the bulk phase to the surface. In this study, MDL was greatly reduced with a very simple strategy, and the cycling stability of the adsorbent was improved.
